sentences.sentence: California and the nation need President Biden's vaccination mandate on companies with more than 100 employees.California and the nation need President Biden's vaccination mandate on companies with more than 100 employees.The new policy is necessary to quell COVID-19 and protect workers from getting the virus and spreading it to their communities.Red states, as expected, are challenging the law's constitutionality.
The U.S. Supreme Court will likely make the final call.
When it does, the court should recognize the law entitles workers to a safe workplace.
Biden's rule does just that.The mandate was scheduled to take effect Jan. 4, but on Saturday a federal appeals court in Louisiana temporarily blocked it.
The panel of three judges, appointed by Republican presidents, were scheduled to hear arguments Monday afternoon on whether the temporary order should be made permanent.Vaccination mandates work.
They help prevent infection and for most people minimize the symptoms of those who do get sick.

Vaccines are the best tool available to slow the spread of a deadly virus that has killed more than 70,000 Californians and 750,000 Americans.After a brief slowdown, California's case rate is climbing again and is now twice Florida's case rate.
We have seen this cycle far too many times when state and local officials loosen COVID-19 restrictions.

California's vaccination rate (62%) is higher than many other states, but it is not nearly high enough for herd immunity to take effect ᅳ not when one out of every three Californians remain unvaccinated.Biden's mandate is designed to be implemented on an emergency basis by the Department of Labor.
The policy requires weekly testing and mandatory wearing of face masks for workers who do not get vaccinated.

It also provides that businesses must provide paid time off for workers to get their vaccinations and requires employers to continue paying employees if they suffer side effects from the shots.The White House is not asking small businesses to comply, believing that they do not have the workforce necessary to avoid disruption in the workplace.San Jose offers a prime example of the effectiveness of employer mandates.When the city announced a mandate for all city employees, more than 100 police officers said they were prepared to quit the police force because of it.
But as of last Thursday, only six city employees had chosen to forfeit a week of pay for the option to stay unvaccinated.
That means 95% of all city employees had submitted proof that they are fully vaccinated.
That includes about 100 police officers.
All told, 92% of the 1,146 sworn officers have had their shots.New York City tells a similar story.
Mayor Bill De Blasio invoked a vaccine mandate for city employees, and his office said Thursday that 92% of the city's total workforce had received at lease one dose of the coronavirus.
The fire department and police department's vaccination rate is about 85%, according to data released by the mayor's office.

The state's vaccination rate stands at 67%.The Department of Labor said that it estimates Biden's vaccine mandate for employers will prevent more than 250,000 hospitalizations and save thousands of lives.

Implementing the White House's requirement will prevent the devastating impact COVID-19 has had in California and throughout America.A 45-year-old Hilo man was sentenced Aug. 22 to 10 years for a domestic assault last Christmas Eve on his estranged girlfriend.A 64-year-old Ocean View man accused of killing one of his dogs has been freed from custody on supervised release, a form of cashless bail.Hilo High School has installed a new artificial turf football field as part of an $11-million upgrade project, which will also include a cutting-edge rubberized track.

Contractor Nan Inc. began construction on the project in Dec. 2023, following a design and planning process that started in 2017.NEW YORK ᅳ Lou Piniella was back in uniform Saturday, wearing pinstripes and the number 14 for Old-Timers' Day at Yankee Stadium.
Piniella, who turns 81 next week, earned his fame in the Bronx as a two-time World Series champion but spent much of his managing career in a feisty rivalry with the Y

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: California and the nation need President Biden’s vaccination mandate on companies with more than 100 employees.California and the nation need President Biden’s vaccination mandate on companies with more than 100 employees.The new policy is necessary to quell COVID-19 and protect workers from getting the virus and spreading it to their communities.Red states, as expected, are challenging the law’s constitutionality. The U.S. Supreme Court will likely make the final call. When it does, the court should recognize the law entitles workers to a safe workplace. Biden’s rule does just that.The mandate was scheduled to take effect Jan. 4, but on Saturday a federal appeals court in Louisiana temporarily blocked it. The panel of three judges, appointed by Republican presidents, were scheduled to hear arguments Monday afternoon on whether the temporary order should be made permanent.Vaccination mandates work. They help prevent infection and for most people minimize the symptoms of those who do get sick. Vaccines are the best tool available to slow the spread of a deadly virus that has killed more than 70,000 Californians and 750,000 Americans.After a brief slowdown, California’s case rate is climbing again and is now twice Florida’s case rate. We have seen this cycle far too many times when state and local officials loosen COVID-19 restrictions. California’s vaccination rate (62%) is higher than many other states, but it is not nearly high enough for herd immunity to take effect — not when one out of every three Californians remain unvaccinated.Biden’s mandate is designed to be implemented on an emergency basis by the Department of Labor. The policy requires weekly testing and mandatory wearing of face masks for workers who do not get vaccinated. It also provides that businesses must provide paid time off for workers to get their vaccinations and requires employers to continue paying employees if they suffer side effects from the shots.The White House is not asking small businesses to comply, believing that they do not have the workforce necessary to avoid disruption in the workplace.San Jose offers a prime example of the effectiveness of employer mandates.When the city announced a mandate for all city employees, more than 100 police officers said they were prepared to quit the police force because of it. But as of last Thursday, only six city employees had chosen to forfeit a week of pay for the option to stay unvaccinated. That means 95% of all city employees had submitted proof that they are fully vaccinated. That includes about 100 police officers. All told, 92% of the 1,146 sworn officers have had their shots.New York City tells a similar story. Mayor Bill De Blasio invoked a vaccine mandate for city employees, and his office said Thursday that 92% of the city’s total workforce had received at lease one dose of the coronavirus. The fire department and police department’s vaccination rate is about 85%, according to data released by the mayor’s office. The state’s vaccination rate stands at 67%.The Department of Labor said that it estimates Biden’s vaccine mandate for employers will prevent more than 250,000 hospitalizations and save thousands of lives. Implementing the White House’s requirement will prevent the devastating impact COVID-19 has had in California and throughout America.A 45-year-old Hilo man was sentenced Aug. 22 to 10 years for a domestic assault last Christmas Eve on his estranged girlfriend.A 64-year-old Ocean View man accused of killing one of his dogs has been freed from custody on supervised release, a form of cashless bail.Hilo High School has installed a new artificial turf football field as part of an $11-million upgrade project, which will also include a cutting-edge rubberized track. Contractor Nan Inc. began construction on the project in Dec. 2023, following a design and planning process that started in 2017.NEW YORK — Lou Piniella was back in uniform Saturday, wearing pinstripes and the number 14 for Old-Timers’ Day at Yankee Stadium. Piniella, who turns 81 next week, earned his fame in the Bronx as a two-time World Series champion but spent much of his managing career in a feisty rivalry with the Y
